DOC.brief_title: Safety Efficacy PVDF ( DynaMesh®-SIS Soft ) Retropubic Midurethral Slings Stress Urinary Incontinence Women
DOC.detailed_description: This study design evaluate safety efficacy low elasticity polyvinylidene fluoride ( DynaMesh®-SIS soft ) retropubic tension-free midurethral sling treatment stress urinary incontinence ( SUI ) woman . Stress urinary incontinence common problem , affect large number woman . If conservative measure ineffective surgery offer . Surgery involve permanent mesh sling place , tension free beneath midurethra . The standard retropubic tension-free vaginal tape ( TVT ) use since 1996 use polypropylene mesh . ( 1 ) The use permanent mesh gynaecology come scrutiny due significant complication woman . ( 2 ) This year Medicines Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency ( MHRA ) , UK conclude enough evidence withdraw mesh clinical usage . ( 3 ) The sling studied DynaMesh®SIS soft , make polyvinylidene fluoride ( PVDF ) improve biocompatibility tissue , mean reduce scar formation less mesh shrinkage . ( 4 ) Each sling individually woven low elasticity meaning dimension maintain tension , cough straining . The technique retropubic placement DynaMesh®SIS soft differ current retropubic TVT placement . The hypothesis low elasticity polyvinylidene fluoride midurethral sling non-inferior safety efficacy compare safety efficacy traditional polypropylene sling , report current literature . There eight research centre three country , The United Kingdom , Ireland Germany . The DynaMesh®SIS soft sling currently use four eight research hospital , Norwich ( main research centre ) , Antrim Belfast UK Munich Germany . It introduce London , Cambridge Huntingdon UK Dublin Ireland . Women urodynamic stress incontinence already assign retropubic midurethral tape place treatment recruit prior procedure ongoing follow . Participants complete standardise urinary incontinence quality life questionnaires prior procedure 3,6,12 , 18 24 month post . Clinical follow occur 3 12 month post operatively required concern .
